qas.question: When did political and religious changes alter the attitude of historians towards John?
Which historians were favourably inclined towards the king?
What praised John's "great renown" as a king?

answers.text: John Speed's Historie of Great Britaine

context: In the <a0_0>16th century<a0_0/> political and religious changes altered the attitude of historians towards John. <a1_0>Tudor historians<a1_0/> were generally favourably inclined towards the king, focusing on John's opposition to the Papacy and his promotion of the special rights and prerogatives of a king. Revisionist histories written by John Foxe, William Tyndale and Robert Barnes portrayed John as an early Protestant hero, and John Foxe included the king in his Book of Martyrs. <a2_0>John Speed's Historie of Great Britaine<a2_0/> in 1632 praised John's "great renown" as a king; he blamed the bias of medieval chroniclers for the king's poor reputation.
